ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: individual readings

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: How to become a better writer through the analysis of text, workshops, and by writing myself.
Developed my writing and editing skills, and I gained confidence in my ability to write.
The class is focused on creative nonfiction writing. We covered four units, each pertaining to a particular type of essay (experience, place, cultural artifact, and profile of a person).

The main skill that I developed from taking this course was my essay writing skills. We wrote four essays throughout the year that were each written over a two week period. Because the rough drafts were due after the first week, I was given a lot of time to revise and change my essay for the second week. Aside from this, my grammar was improved significantly by reading the works of famous authors and their essays.

drastically improved my writing abilities 
my critical analysis of texts improved

This course gave me the knowledge of many great essays centered on the subjects of people, places, things, and experiences. I learned how to be a better reading, and by doing so a better writer by copying the strategies of the great works I read and by practicing employing them in my own writing.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved? (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Not many...the professor is very considerate, available, and teaches very well.
The class is well designed and very helpful for writing.

Professor Deli was an absolute delight to take English 120 with.  She is extremely friendly and made a thorough effort to get to know each of us personally.  While it is generally hard to get anything above an A- in the class, Professor Deli was fair and transparent with grading as well. The course itself was structured quite nicely. We covered four units, each pertaining to a particular type of creative nonfiction essay. One of the strengths of the class was being able to workshop our peers' essays. This allowed for us to have plenty of feedback when writing our own essays, and led to some very thought-provoking classes. 

While we did engage with some very interesting readings, it often felt like our discussions were a bit tangential, and did not address how we could implement the writing techniques used in these readings. It would have been helpful to spend more time discussing principles of writing, as I felt that our engagement with the assigned readings was a bit disjointed from the writing we did.

The strengths of this course are that there is a lot of room to improve your essay writing. My professor gave me many opportunities to improve. Another strength is that my professor was willing to meet with me outside of the class times in a 1 on 1 session. These sessions gave me a lot of help because I was able to ask her questions the essays, the reading material, and the in-class discussions.

The strengths included the open discussion and the fact that there were not pre-planned questions. This allowed the discussion to focus on those points which the students and professor found to be most useful. I do not believe there to be any weaknesses of it.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Using breakout rooms to allow for one-on-one interactions was quite useful.

I do not think that much can be improved in this course. My professor did a great job adjusting for the effects of the pandemic and was very lenient if asked nicely. The practices that succeeded were always being energetic, kind, and supportive. Never was there a time where my teacher was upset or treated anyone harshly.
Zoom succeeded very well, as well as the heavier reliance upon Canvas. I don't think there's anything that could be improved.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: YES! This was one of if not the best class that I have taken.
Absolutely. This class should be required for all yale students.

I would recommend this course to any student, regardless of their major. This class allows for students to exercise writing skills that most English classes do not spend time developing. While it can be a bit challenging at first, especially for students accustomed to academic writing, I did significantly improve in my ability to write creative nonfiction essays. The course workload is evenly distributed throughout the semester, which is quite nice during finals period.

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. In high school, English was never my favorite subject. But, this class quickly became my favorite during my time at Yale. The professor is very kind and the material that I learnt was very interesting. Most importantly, I became a much better writer which was one of my major goals for the course in the beginning of the year.
yes, the instructor works hard while also making the course very engaging
Yes, indeed. This class was very friendly and allowed budding writers to make mistakes in a friendly environment that cultured a sense of growth and not criticism.
